original: Boethius, Carl Axel, professor, Göteborg, f. 18/7/89 i Arvika av prof. Simon Johannes B. o. Essie Sahlin. G. 18 m. Madeleine Björnberg. Barn: Jan Fredrik f. 20, Lilly Renata 23. — Stud:ex. v. Upps. ensk. lärov. o. priv:-gymn. 07, fil. ämb:ex. v. Upps. univ. 14, fil. lic. där s. å., fil. dr 18. Mu-seistud. i Danm. o. Tyskl. 13-14, delt. i eng. arkeol. inst. grävn. i Grekl. 21-22, sv. inst. i Rom utgrävn. i Ardea 29-35, museistud. i Amerika 32-33, i Engl. 22, 32 o. 37. Doc. i Upps. 18-25, förest, f. sv. inst. i Rom 26-35, prof. namn 27, prof. i klassisk fornkunsk. o. antikens hist. v. Gbgs högsk. 35, rektor v. Gbgs högsk. sed. 46. Charles Elliot Norton kcturer of the archæol Inst. of America 32-33, Sv :e-Amerika-stift. Zornstip. s. å., Gray lecturer v. univ. i Cambridge 37, visiting prof. v. imiv. i Chicago 38. Hemv :omr :befälh. f. Gbgs v. hemv :omr. 40-45. Friv. i Finl. frihikrig 18. Av K. M :t för-ordn. ordf. f. Riksfören. f, svenskh. bev. i uti. sed. 44, medl. av Accade-mia Pontificia d’Archeoilogia 33, av Accad. dei Virtuosi al Pantheon 33, av Accad. di San Luca 47, av Finska VA 47, av The Weistermarck Soc. 47, av Inst. f. sammenlign. kulturforskn. 46, LVVS 38, LHA 41, led. av Det Kongl. Danske Videnskab. Selsk. 46. Skr.: Framställningar av antikens hist. i Bonniers o. Lindblads världshist., Hur Rom byggdes under antiken (38), Roman architecture from its classicistic to its late imperial phase (41), Den romerska hyresarkitekturen o. dess bebyggelsegeogr. sammanhang (44), Bland sv. minnen i Rom (46), medred. f. Sv. Tidskr. 23-24, f. Le Nord 43. RNO, KFinlLOlkl, KltKrOIkl, KFinl-VR02kl, KNS:t002kl, FFrK2 o. 4kl m. m.
translated:
Boethius, Carl Axel, professor, Gothenburg, born on 18th of July 1889 in Arvika to Professor Simon Johannes B. and Essie Sahlin. Married to Madeleine Björnberg in 18xx. Children: Jan Fredrik, born in 1920 and Lilly Renata, born in 1923. 
He obtained his high school diploma from Uppsala private high school and gymnasium in 1907. He received his Bachelor's Degree in Philosophy from Uppsala University in 1914, then his Master's Degree in Philosophy from the same university later on that year, followed by his Doctorate in Philosophy in 1918. He studied at a museum in Denmark and Germany from 1913-1914, participated in archaeological excavations in Greece as part of the English Archaeological Institute in 1921-1922, conducted excavation studies in Ardea as part of the Swedish Institute in Rome from 1929-1935, studied museums in America in 1932-1933 and in England in 1922, 1932, and 1937. 
He was a Docent at Uppsala University from 1918-1925, Head of the Swedish Institute in Rome from 1926-1935, Full Professor and Head of the Classics Department at Gothenburg University from 1935, and he served as the Rector of Gothenburg University from 1946. He was Charles Elliot Norton lecturer at the Archaeological Institute of America in 1932-1933, and was a Fellow of the Zorn Foundation of Sweden the same year. He was also the Gray lecturer at the University of Cambridge in 1937, Visiting Professor at the University of Chicago in 1938, and served as the commander of the Home Guard in Gothenburg between 1940 and 1945. He volunteered in the Finnish War of Independence in 1918. He was appointed chairman of the National Association for Swedish Heritage Preservation Abroad by the King in 1944 and was a member of the Pontifical Academy of Archaeology in 1933, the Academy of Virtuosi at the Pantheon in 1933, the San Luca Academy in 1947, the Finnish Academy in 1947, the Weistermarck Society in 1947, the Institute for Comparative Cultural Research in 1946, the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences in 1938, and the Royal Danish Academy of Sciences in 1946. He authored several books including presentations on the history of antiquities in Bonniers and Lindblads' world history, How Rome was built during antiquity (1938), Roman architecture from its classicistic to its late imperial phase (1941), The Roman rental architecture and its geographical context of buildings (1944), and Among Swedish memories in Rome (1946), and also served as co-editor for the Swedish Journal from 1923-1924 and for Le Nord in 1943. Boethius was awarded the Royal Order of the North Star, the Order of the White Rose of Finland, the Order of the Lion and the Sun, the Order of the Polar Star, the French Academy Award, and the Order of the Finnish War Cross 2nd Class.
